awd_titl_txt: Anticipating rates of deglaciation in Alaska: Controls on the mass loss and morphology of the debris covered terminus of Kennicott Glacier, Wrangell - St. Elias National Park
awd_abstract_narration:
Landscapes in glacial environments change rapidly due to shrinking glaciers. Many glaciers in Alaska are covered by a layer of rocks and sediment, but there are very few direct measurements of how these debris-covered glaciers decay and affect glacier decline. The debris cover is expected to suppress glacier melting, but studies in the Himalayas have shown that many heavily debris-covered glacier tongues thin and decay just as fast as similar debris-free glaciers. The underlying mechanisms for this more rapid than expected glacier change are not well understood. Very limited observations exist in Alaska, where many glaciers are heavily debris-covered. A better understanding of these glaciers is necessary to develop better models predicting how they will melt and affect landscapes in the future.

The overall goal of this project is to investigate the role of debris cover in modulating glacier surface and glacier mass change on the declining Kennicott Glacier in Alaska. The researchers will characterize the debris cover and observe the pattern and rate of dynamic change of the debris-covered lower reaches of Kennicott Glacier using field observations and remote sensing, to quantify the effect of debris cover on the annual mass change of the entire glacier. They will collect field data including meteorological and mass balance observations to constrain modeling on both detailed and larger spatial scales. The goal is to develop a model that can parameterize both melt suppression under thick debris and melt enhancement across ice cliffs, making it suitable for application on a regional scale. The project will provide training for several students, and field study examples for an international class of glaciology graduate students attending a successful summer school at this site. It also allows the work to be used by several local educational programs outside glaciology. What is learned about changing glaciers at this site will be available to visitors of Wrangell-Saint Elias National Park.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many glaciers have a debris layer, composed of rocks, silt, and sand, covering their lower regions. This layer influences the energy exchange at the surface, thereby impacting the rate of glacier melt. Understanding the role of debris cover in glacier mass changes is crucial for making accurate projections of glacier contributions to sea-level rise, streamflow, and landscape evolution.

This project investigated the role of debris cover in glacier melt on Kennicott Glacier, Alaska using extensive field observations during the melt seasons 2020-2023. These included measurements of glacier mass change, meteorological variables and debris properties. Debris-cover thickness measurements at 150 sites varied from <1 to 69 cm with an average of 17 cm. Melt rates were much lower over the debris-covered ice than over clean ice at similar elevations. We developed a relationship between melt rate and debris thickness, predicting an exponential decrease in melt as debris thickness increases. This relationship can be applied to melt modeling for debris-covered glaciers.

We also investigated the role of ice cliffs, i.e. near-vertical debris-free ice faces that tend to develop in the hummocky debris-covered terrain. Melt rates (perpendicular to the ice cliff face) were up to 10 times those for debris-covered ice, and even exceeded clean ice melt rates. Backwasting of ice cliffs of more than 8 m was observed indicating that ice cliffs are melt hot spots.

We further investigated the impact of supraglacial streams on ice cliffs using field and remote sensing observations, streamflow measurements, and a conceptual model of ice cliff change. We found that one third of the glacier´s ice cliffs (accounting for almost 70 % of the ice cliff area) are actively influenced by streams, while half are closer than 10 m from the nearest stream. Streams on the glacier surface contributed directly to ice cliff formation and maintenance by horizontal meandering, vertical erosion, and debris transport. These processes produce an undercut lip at the ice cliff base and transport sediment clasts up to tens of centimeters in diameter, preventing reburial of ice cliffs by debris. Stream meanders similar in shape to river channel meanders outside glaciers produce sinuous and crescent ice cliff shapes. Rapid abandonments of the stream channel and formation of new channels result in rapid ice cliff collapse and local channel abandonment. Ice cliffs abandoned by streams are observed to be reburied by debris atop the ice surface, indicating a strong role played by streams in ice cliff persistence. Using satellite images, we also detected a localized surge-like event at the glacier’s western margin, i.e. an speedup in ice flow, which caused the formation of ice cliffs from crevassing.

Glacier melt under a surface layer of rocky debris is typically calculated from the heat transferred via conduction through the debris layer. However, heat can also be transferred in the debris layer through other nonconductive processes such as air movement and the evaporation of melt water in the porous debris cover. We analyzed time series of debris temperature data and developed a novel method to calculate the conductive and nonconductive heat flux components. Results indicate that nonconductive heat fluxes are significant, accounting for up to 43% of heat transferred via conduction. We conclude that this process must be investigated further and incorporated into models of glacier melt for accurate melt calculations.

Overall, this project delivered an extensive data set of a highly debris-covered glacier and provided new insights into the processes driving glacier melt of debris-covered glaciers which will be beneficial for glaciological and landscape evolution modeling. The results are relevant also to modeling permafrost just going beyond the study of glaciers.

Results were disseminated to broader audiences through publications, scientific and popular science presentations. An undergraduate student participated in the field work and received training in glaciological data collection and analyses.
